long_desc.thetext: reconstruct -r does not reconstruct for sub-directories, apart from Trash. It reconstructs the INBOX and Trash only. My imapd.conf config has the following options (may be not relevant): altnamespace: 1 unixhierarchysep: 1
Can you verify the sub-directories are actually mailbox folders -and recognized as such?

Hello Jeroen. Actually these are copies of /var/spool/imap of another system (under Cyrus-imapd 2.3.11 I think). How do you want me to verify they are recognized as mailbox folders ?
[root@linux2 deuxtest]# pwd /var/spool/imap/d/user/deuxtest [root@linux2 deuxtest]# ls -l total 48 -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 633 18 avril 18:06 1. drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:49 aconserver -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 732 18 avril 18:06 cyrus.cache -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 158 18 avril 16:54 cyrus.header -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 224 18 avril 18:06 cyrus.index drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 Deleted Messages drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 Drafts drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 Notes drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 pubnews drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 Sent drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 Sent Messages drwx------ 2 cyrus mail 4096 18 avril 16:54 Trash [root@linux2 deuxtest]# ls -l aconserver/ total 280 -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 1389 22 sept. 2009 1. -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 91736 22 sept. 2009 2. -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 21572 5 oct. 2009 3. -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 162589 8 oct. 2009 4. [root@linux2 deuxtest]# /usr/cyrus/bin/reconstruct -r user/deuxtest user/deuxtest user/deuxtest/Trash

ctl_mboxlist -d | grep deuxtest
Reconstruct doesn't look at the filesystem by default, only at the mailboxes.db.
I'm guessing INBOX and Trash got created by external events (i.e. a client connecting that creates Trash)
Have you tried adding the '-f' option to reconstruct?
-f Examine the filesystem underneath mailbox, adding all directo‐ ries with a cyrus.header found there as new mailboxes. Useful for restoring mailboxes from backups.

[root@linux2 deuxtest]# /usr/cyrus/bin/ctl_mboxlist -d user.backup 0 default backup lrswipkxtecda user.backup.Trash 0 default backup lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest.Trash 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.social 0 default social lrswipkxtecda user.social.Trash 0 default social lrswipkxtecda user.test 0 default test lrswipkxtecda user.test.Trash 0 default test lrswipkxtecda user.test.sousod 0 default test lrswipkxtecda
What I notice is that there is no user.deuxtest.aconserver in the list.
[root@linux2 deuxtest]# /usr/cyrus/bin/reconstruct -r -f user/deuxtest user/deuxtest user/deuxtest/Trash
No change with -f option.
Do you mean I need to create manually the sub-mailboxes (using cyradm) before running the above command ?
Thanks for your assistance

That would be the quickest solution to your problem, I suppose.
That said, seems like we've got a bug with -f not examining the filesystem as closely as we'd like.

Fair enough - that sounds like a legitimate bug to hang on this number :)
What happens if you add -p default as well to set the partition to search?
It would be better if reconstruct either:
a) searched the partition of the parent mailbox (if it exists), or:
b) searched ALL partitions.
I can't really think of a good reason not to do (b) by default when -f is specified.
Bron.

-p option is rejected:
[root@linux2 deuxtest]# /usr/cyrus/bin/reconstruct -p /var/spool/imap -f user/deuxtest Mailbox user/deuxtest already exists. Cannot specify -p.
Thanks

[root@linux2 deuxtest]# ls -l aconserver/ total 280 -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 1389 22 sept. 2009 1. -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 91736 22 sept. 2009 2. -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 21572 5 oct. 2009 3. -rw------- 1 cyrus mail 162589 8 oct. 2009 4.
Oh - duh. There's no cyrus.* files in here!. Of course it didn't detect them.
Did you perhaps forget to copy those? Maybe you had split meta on the old server and don't have it on the new server?
This isn't a bug - it's a misuse of the tool. You need to copy the meta files as well, or Cyrus can't tell that it's actually a mailbox directory and not some random junk on the disk.
Now... there is a possible theory that it should be able to create a new mailbox in directories that don't have a cyrus.header as well, but that's a pretty big change in behaviour. I'd want to at least check there was a message file in there first...
FYI - I'm running a poll on the mailing lists for changing the behaviour of -f.

[root@linux2 deuxtest]# /usr/cyrus/bin/ctl_mboxlist -d ... user.deuxtest 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest.Drafts 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest.Notes 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest.Sent 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest.Trash 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda user.deuxtest.aconserver 0 default deuxtest lrswipkxtecda ...
If I open Thunderbird on that mail box, I still cannot see "aconserver".
Looks perfectly reconstructed to me. Reconstructing is different from subscribing - you may need to go in with Thunderbird and subscribe to the folder before you can see it.

I think we determined it wasn't a bug in the end :)
